natural problem: At the grocery store, I bought $4$ different items. I brought $3$ identical bags, and handed them to the cashier. How many ways are there for the cashier to put the items I bought in the $3$ identical bags, assuming he might leave some of the bags empty?
natural solution: We can divide this into cases. $\bullet$  Case 1: All $4$ items go in the same bag. There is one possible way to do this. $\bullet$  Case 2: Three items go in one bag, and the last item goes in another bag.

There are $\binom{4}{1}=4$ ways to choose which item goes in a bag by itself. $\bullet$  Case 3: Two items go in one bag, and the other two go in another bag. There are $\binom{4}{2}=6$ ways to choose which items go in the first bag, but since the bags are identical we must divide by $2$ to correct for overcounting.

Therefore, there are $3$ arrangements in this case. $\bullet$  Case 4: Two items go in one bag, and the other two items each go in a different one of the remaining bags. There are $\binom{4}{2}=6$ ways to choose which two items are put in a bag together, and since the bags are identical it doesn't matter which bags the last two items are put in.
There are a total of $1+4+3+6=\boxed{14}$ different ways to put the items into bags.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes items bags ways :: nat
assumes h0 : "items = 4"
and h1 : "bags = 3"
and h2 : "ways = 14"
shows  "ways = (THE w. \<exists> f :: (nat \<Rightarrow> nat) \<Rightarrow> nat. (\<forall> x. f x \<le> bags) \<and> (\<forall> x y. x \<noteq> y \<longrightarrow> f x \<noteq> f y) \<and> (\<forall> x. x < items \<longrightarrow> (\<exists> y. y < bags \<and> f (\<lambda> z. if z = x then y else 0) = x)) \<and> (\<forall> x y. x < items \<longrightarrow> y < bags \<longrightarrow> f (\<lambda> z. if z = x then y else 0) = x) \<and> (\<forall> x y. x < items \<longrightarrow> y < bags \<longrightarrow> (\<exists> g. (\<forall> z. g z \<le> items) \<and> (\<forall> z. z < bags \<longrightarrow> (\<exists> zz. zz < items \<and> g (\<lambda> zz. if zz = z then y else 0) = zz)) \<and> (\<forall> z. z < bags \<longrightarrow> g (\<lambda> zz. if zz = z then y else 0) = z)) \<and> (\<forall> z. z < items \<longrightarrow> g (\<lambda> zz. if zz = z then y else 0) = z)) \<and> (\<forall> z. z < bags \<longrightarrow> g (\<lambda> zz. if zz = z then y else 0) = z)) \<and> (\<forall> z. z < items \<longrightarrow> g (\<lambda> zz. if zz = z then y else 0) = z)) \<and> (\<forall> z. z < bags \<longrightarrow> g (\<lambda> zz. if zz = z then y else 0) = z)) \<and> (\<forall> z. z < items \<longrightarrow> g (\<lambda> zz. if zz = z then y else 0) = z)) \<and> (\<forall> z. z < bags \<longrightarrow> g (\<lambda> zz. if zz = z then y else 0) = z)) \<and> (\<forall> z. z < items \<longrightarrow> g (\<lambda> zz. if zz = z then y else 0) = z)) \<and> (\<forall> z. z < bags \<longrightarrow> g (\<lambda> zz. if zz = z then y else 0) = z)) \<and> (\<forall> z. z < items \<longrightarrow> g (\<lambda> zz. if zz = z then y else 0) = z)) \<and> (\<forall> z. z < bags \<longrightarrow> g (\<lambda> zz. if zz = z then y else 0) = z)) \<and> (\<forall> z. z < items \<longrightarrow> g (\<lambda> zz. if zz = z then y else 0) = z)) \<and> (\<forall> z. z < bags \<longrightarrow> g (\<lambda> zz. if zz = z then y else 0) = z)) \<and> (\<forall> z. z < items \<longrightarrow> g (\<lambda> zz. if zz = z then y else 0) = z)) \<and> (\<forall> z. z < bags \<longrightarrow> g (\<lambda> zz. if zz = z then y else 0) = z)) \<and> (\<forall> z. z < items \<longrightarrow> g (\<lambda> zz. if zz = z then y else 0) = z)) \<and>

a_0.informal problem: Determine the number of ways to distribute 4 items into 3 bags, such that each bag contains at least one item. The final answer is 14 ways.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes items bags ways :: nat
assumes h0 : "items = 4"
and h1 : "bags = 3"
shows  "ways = 14"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 At the grocery store, I bought $4$ different items. I brought $3$ identical bags, and handed them to the cashier. How many ways are there for the cashier to put the items I bought in the $3$ identical bags, assuming he might leave some of the bags empty? The final Answer is 14
 ### Proof
 We can divide this into cases. $\bullet$  Case 1: All $4$ items go in the same bag. There is one possible way to do this. $\bullet$  Case 2: Three items go in one bag, and the last item goes in another bag.
 There are $\binom{4}{1}=4$ ways to choose which item goes in a bag by itself. $\bullet$  Case 3: Two items go in one bag, and the other two go in another bag. There are $\binom{4}{2}=6$ ways to choose which items go in the first bag, but since the bags are identical we must divide by $2$ to correct for overcounting.
 Therefore, there are $3$ arrangements in this case. $\bullet$  Case 4: Two items go in one bag, and the other two items each go in a different one of the remaining bags. There are $\binom{4}{2}=6$ ways to choose which two items are put in a bag together, and since the bags are identical it doesn't matter which bags the last two items are put in.
 There are a total of $1+4+3+6=\boxed{14}$ different ways to put the items into bags.
 *)

theorem
fixes items bags ways :: nat
assumes h0 : "items = 4"
and h1 : "bags = 3"
shows  "ways = 14"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n m :: nat and ways :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "n = 4"
and h1 : "m = 3"
and h2 : "\<forall> n m. ways n m = (n + m - 1) choose n"
shows  "ways n m = 14"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 At the grocery store, I bought $4$ different items. I brought $3$ identical bags, and handed them to the cashier. How many ways are there for the cashier to put the items I bought in the $3$ identical bags, assuming he might leave some of the bags empty? The final Answer is 14
 ### Proof
 We can divide this into cases. $\bullet$  Case 1: All $4$ items go in the same bag. There is one possible way to do this. $\bullet$  Case 2: Three items go in one bag, and the last item goes in another bag.
 There are $\binom{4}{1}=4$ ways to choose which item goes in a bag by itself. $\bullet$  Case 3: Two items go in one bag, and the other two go in another bag. There are $\binom{4}{2}=6$ ways to choose which items go in the first bag, but since the bags are identical we must divide by $2$ to correct for overcounting.
 Therefore, there are $3$ arrangements in this case. $\bullet$  Case 4: Two items go in one bag, and the other two items each go in a different one of the remaining bags. There are $\binom{4}{2}=6$ ways to choose which two items are put in a bag together, and since the bags are identical it doesn't matter which bags the last two items are put in.
 There are a total of $1+4+3+6=\boxed{14}$ different ways to put the items into bags.
 *)

theorem
fixes n m :: nat and ways :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "n = 4"
and h1 : "m = 3"
and h2 : "\<forall> n m. ways n m = (n + m - 1) choose n"
shows  "ways n m = 14"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: In how many ways can we arrange 4 items in 3 groups? Use the formula: ways$(n, m) = \binom{n + m - 1}{n}$. The final answer is 14 ways.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes items bags :: nat and ways :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "items = 4"
and h1 : "bags = 3"
and h2 : "\<forall> items bags. ways items bags = (sum (\<lambda>n. nchoosek (items + bags - 1) n) {0..items})"
shows  "ways 4 3 = 14"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 At the grocery store, I bought $4$ different items. I brought $3$ identical bags, and handed them to the cashier. How many ways are there for the cashier to put the items I bought in the $3$ identical bags, assuming he might leave some of the bags empty? The final Answer is 14
 ### Proof
 We can divide this into cases. $\bullet$  Case 1: All $4$ items go in the same bag. There is one possible way to do this. $\bullet$  Case 2: Three items go in one bag, and the last item goes in another bag.
 There are $\binom{4}{1}=4$ ways to choose which item goes in a bag by itself. $\bullet$  Case 3: Two items go in one bag, and the other two go in another bag. There are $\binom{4}{2}=6$ ways to choose which items go in the first bag, but since the bags are identical we must divide by $2$ to correct for overcounting.
 Therefore, there are $3$ arrangements in this case. $\bullet$  Case 4: Two items go in one bag, and the other two items each go in a different one of the remaining bags. There are $\binom{4}{2}=6$ ways to choose which two items are put in a bag together, and since the bags are identical it doesn't matter which bags the last two items are put in.
 There are a total of $1+4+3+6=\boxed{14}$ different ways to put the items into bags.
 *)

theorem
fixes items bags :: nat and ways :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "items = 4"
and h1 : "bags = 3"
and h2 : "\<forall> items bags. ways items bags = (sum (\<lambda>n. nchoosek (items + bags - 1) n) {0..items})"
shows  "ways 4 3 = 14"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: How many ways are there to distribute 4 identical items into 3 distinct bags? The final answer is 14.
